importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update on global progress and challenges in early warning systems for extreme weather, as part of the ongoing climate crisis response.

The collapse of the Swiss mountain glacier in May 2025, which prompted evacuation of the village of Blatten, exemplifies a real-world application of early warning systems in response to climate-induced natural hazards.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The year 2025 is highlighted as a period of intensified weather-related disasters, including floods and wildfires, emphasizing the urgency of global early warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, increasing vulnerability, especially in developing nations.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
The WMO reports that 16% of assessed countries have less than basic capacity, and half have only basic capacity, indicating a significant global gap.
Despite progress, the situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
The WMO has seen improvement in Africa, with more countries establishing functional early warning websites and standardized alerts.
The 2025 disasters—floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea; wildfires in southern Europe and the US—demonstrate the widespread and growing impact of climate change.
The collapse of a Swiss mountain glacier in May 2025 led to the evacuation of Blatten, showing the life-saving potential of early warning systems.
Permafrost melt is expected to increase the frequency of glacier collapses and rockfalls, reinforcing the need for robust monitoring and alerts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, has issued a global call for improved early warning systems for extreme weather, noting that nearly half of countries lack sufficient monitoring and forecasting capacity. Over the past 50 years, weather, water, and climate-related hazards have caused over 2 million deaths, with 90% occurring in developing nations. The WMO highlights that 16% of assessed countries have less than basic alert systems, and progress is particularly limited in fragile and conflict-affected regions. Despite some advances—such as in Africa—the situation remains dire. Real-world examples like the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland, which led to the evacuation of Blatten, underscore the life-saving potential of early warnings. As climate change intensifies, the article stresses that timely alerts and early action are essential to saving lives and protecting economic and infrastructure assets worldwide.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
